metadata.title: We Have Always Lived in the Castle
metadata.author: Shirley Jackson

layer_1_whats_happening.who_tells_it: Merricat Blackwood tells the story from her own point of view, but she sees the world very differently from most people.
layer_1_whats_happening.what_we_experience: Two sisters live alone in their family house after a poisoning killed most of their family, but their isolated life gets threatened when a cousin arrives.
layer_1_whats_happening.how_it_feels: We start feeling sorry for the sisters, but gradually become uncomfortable and horrified as we realize what's really happening.

layer_2_meaning_by_section.meaning: Jackson creates a fairy tale feeling that hides the dark truth about this family.
layer_2_meaning_by_section.quote: our house was built up with layers
layer_2_meaning_by_section.devices_supporting: Metaphors make the house feel magical and protective, while the game motif ('lose one turn') makes dangerous situations seem playful rather than serious.

layer_2_meaning_by_section.meaning: Merricat's grip on reality weakens as she desperately tries to protect her perfect world from change.
layer_2_meaning_by_section.devices_supporting: Her unreliable narration shows how she lies to herself, trying to convince herself and Constance that Charles isn't real because she can't handle his presence.

layer_2_meaning_by_section.meaning: Merricat's magical thinking leads to real destruction when she starts the fire.
layer_2_meaning_by_section.quote: I twisted the winding knob backward until there was a small complaining crack
layer_2_meaning_by_section.devices_supporting: The broken watch symbolizes her attempt to stop time and change, while foreshadowing hints at the disaster coming, and juxtaposition shows how differently she sees things.

layer_2_meaning_by_section.meaning: The villagers' violence reveals everyone's true nature while Merricat avoids taking responsibility.
layer_2_meaning_by_section.quote: The house seemed to shiver when she opened the door
layer_2_meaning_by_section.devices_supporting: Dramatic irony lets us know Charles suspects the wrong sister, while personification makes the house seem like a victim instead of focusing on Merricat's actions.

layer_2_meaning_by_section.meaning: The sisters embrace complete isolation, with Merricat still seeing their tragic situation as a happy ending.
layer_2_meaning_by_section.quote: I will go on my winged horse
layer_2_meaning_by_section.devices_supporting: Her first-person narration maintains the fairy tale tone, while verbal irony in Constance's dark humor shows they've accepted their strange new life.

layer_3_connections.step_1: Merricat's first-person narration lets us see the world exactly as she does, making everything seem magical and justified from her perspective.
layer_3_connections.step_2: Dramatic irony and symbolism help us understand what's really happening beneath her fairy tale version of events.
layer_3_connections.step_3: Together: we feel close to Merricat while gradually realizing she's completely unreliable, creating horror through false intimacy.
layer_3_connections.pattern_explanation: We feel connected to the narrator, but that closeness becomes disturbing as we realize how twisted her thinking really is.

components.story_type: psychological horror disguised as a fairy tale
components.larger_meaning: how people create fantasy worlds to avoid facing terrible truths
components.method: making readers feel close to an unreliable narrator

layer_4_thesis.thesis_sentence: Through Merricat's first-person narration and her magical thinking, Jackson creates a psychological horror disguised as a fairy tale that shows how people create fantasy worlds to avoid facing terrible truths, using our false intimacy with an unreliable narrator to make us complicit in her delusions.
